==Morality and Wealth==
−
Socioeconomic factors are important to consider when looking at moral issues. Taking the impact of wealth on the moral issue such as divorce as US study in 2008 <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.barna.org/barna-update/article/15-familykids/42-new-marriage-and-divorce-statistics-released|title= New Marriage and Divorce Statistics Released |author= Barna Group|date= 31 March 2008 |publisher= Barna Group|accessdate= 19 November 2011}}</ref> suggests that people with an income above $75.000 and a college education only have 22% divorce rate compared to 39% in the group with income below $20.000 per annum. Further benefits of wealth can be derived from crime statistics indicating that crime rates are inversly correlated with GDP<ref>{{cite web|last=Rushton|first=J. Philippe|title=Cross-National Variation in Violent Crime Rates: Race, r-K Theory, and Income|url=http://www.charlesdarwinresearch.org/Crime.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> albeit others find a positive correlation<ref>{{cite web|title=Falling together , The relationship between crime and GDP in America|url=http://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/09/us-crime-and-gdp|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref>. More comprehensive analysis shows that the crime rates increase with inequality of wealth distibution <ref>{{cite web|last=Parsley|first=J.Travis|title=Basic Examination of the Correlation between Crime Rates and Income Inequality|url=http://rri-tmp.wvu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/REU2001-19.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Yoonseok|title=Income Polarization and Crime: A Generalized Index and Evidence from Panel Data|url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~yoolee/research/Polarization_LeeShin.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref>. The comparison of the [[List of countries by income equality]] and the [[List of countries by intentional homicide rate]] gives an visual indication of the importance of wealth distribution. [Redistribution of wealth]] can be achieved by socieaty via taxation. The justification of wealth distribution is a matter of debate between philopsophers, social scientists and polititians <ref>{{cite web|last=Barry|first=Christian|title=Redistribution|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/redistribution/|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> Aritstotle in his [[Nicomachean Ethics]] talks about generosity as a virtue but claims that is is better to be wasteful than stingy with regards to dealing with money.
